I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The Asian Development Bank (ADB) has a long tradition of supporting Indonesia’s 
infrastructure development. Since 1971, ADB has lent $8.1 billion for 90 infrastructure projects 
and programs in Indonesia, or 41% of its total assistance to the country. The energy sector has 
accounted for $3.4 billion, transport and communications for $2.8 billion, and water supply, 
sanitation, and urban development for $1.9 billion. However, ADB support has declined after the 
Asian financial crisis, reflecting a downward trend in infrastructure investment in the region in 
general and in Indonesia in particular. The Government of Indonesia and ADB have been 
concerned about this trend and its negative impact on economic growth and poverty reduction. 
Since  2004,  intensive  high-level  policy  dialogue  has  been  held  to  identify  impediments  to 
infrastructure  investments,  formulate  policy  and  regulatory  reforms  needed  to  revive 
infrastructure development, and determine how ADB could best assist in this endeavor. 
 
2.  At the request of the Government, technical assistance (TA) for supporting infrastructure 
development was added to ADB’s 2005 program for Indonesia. Since the proposed TA was not 
included in the previously agreed assistance program, a clearance was received from ADB 
management for processing it. During fact-finding missions in August and September 2005, an 
understanding was reached with the Government on the goal, purpose, scope, approach, cost 
estimates, and implementation arrangements for the TA that will provide support for policy and 
regulatory  reforms  and  project  transactions  in  the  various  infrastructure  sectors.1  The  TA 
framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  Despite many remarkable achievements in the past, Indonesia’s infrastructure service 
coverage is low by regional standards. There are still about 50 million people without access to 
treated water, 90 million people without electricity, 200 million people without fixed telephone 
lines, and 210 million people without connections to a sewerage network. It is the poor who 
suffer disproportionately from the lack of access to such basic infrastructure services. The 
availability of services is generally lower in rural areas, particularly those outside Java and Bali, 
contributing to regional disparities in development. All infrastructure sectors are facing problems 
and need investment. In the power sector, an additional generation capacity of 1,000–2,000 
megawatts has to be installed annually to avoid the looming power shortages, the electrification 
ratio of only 57% has to be increased, and the financial performance of the State Electricity 
Corporation (PLN) improved. With Indonesia becoming a net oil importer, the domestic use of 
abundant natural gas has to be increased by constructing large pipelines from Sumatra and 
East Kalimantan to the Java market. The road density is among the lowest in Southeast Asia as 
only basic preservation with very little expansion has taken place in the past 8 years. The road 
congestion that pushes up costs for industry and trade has to be eased by improving and 
extending the national arterial road network. A major expansion is also needed in the port and 
airport sectors that are vital for domestic and international trade and passenger traffic in the 
archipelagic  country.  Together  with  rural  electrification,  water  supply  can  make  a  key 
contribution to the Government’s pro-poor agenda as less than 20% of the poor have access to 
safe drinking water. To expand the service coverage, the technical and financial performance of 
the local public water utilities has to be improved. 
 
                                                 
1 The TA first appeared in ADB Business Opportunities (internet edition) on 19 August 2005.

2   
4.  The 1997 financial crisis greatly aggravated the situation as many planned public and 
private infrastructure projects were cancelled or suspended. While Indonesia invested more 
than 5% of its gross domestic product (GDP) in infrastructure before the crisis, this figure has 
fallen well below 3% in the past few years. The Government has set ambitious macroeconomic 
targets for its term ending in 2009: (i) accelerate the GDP growth from 4.5% in 2003 to 7.6% 
(average of 6.6%), (ii) increase the investment/GDP ratio from 20.5% in 2003 to 28.4%, (iii) 
reduce the unemployment rate from 9.7% in 2004 to 5.1%, and (iv) halve the poverty rate from 
16.6% in 2004 to 8.2%. It has identified the acceleration of infrastructure development as 
essential  for  achieving  these  macroeconomic  targets.  Since  the  estimated  investment 
requirements far exceed the available public sector funding,2 the Government wishes to bridge 
the gap with the help of large-scale private sector participation (PSP). 
  
5.  Public-private partnerships (PPPs)—contractual arrangements between the public sector 
and a private sector party for the private delivery of public infrastructure services—are the 
preferred approach for increasing PSP. PPPs frequently involve complementary investments 
and/or services. An example is private investments in power generation that are complemented 
by public investments in power transmission and distribution. In the transport sector, the public 
sector can either implement the network of feeder roads to supplement a privately financed and 
operated toll road, or provide the land required for the toll road. In airports, the public sector can 
provide airside facilities such as runways and aprons, while the private investors focus on 
landside facilities such as terminals and their operation. The PPP in ports can consist of the 
public sector providing the port infrastructure and the private investor being awarded concession 
for port operations.  
 
6.  The Government is aware of the urgent need to improve the investment climate through 
policy  reforms.  These  will  liberalize  markets  and  allow  competition  from  new  entrants, 
strengthen  regulatory  arrangements,  improve  cost  recovery,  and  establish  effective 
mechanisms for dispute resolution. It is a prerequisite for PPPs to separate the three main 
functions—contract management, regulation, and operation—that are performed in some cases 
by state-owned enterprises (SOEs), which dominate Indonesia’s infrastructure sectors. The 
various policy, legal, institutional and other issues—both cross-sectoral and sector-specific—
that impede infrastructure development are summarized in Appendix 2. 
 
7.  At  the  Indonesia  Infrastructure  Summit  (IIS)  held  in  Jakarta  in  January  2005,  the 
President  led  high-level  government  officials  in  expressing  the  political  will  to  accelerate 
infrastructure development and proceed with the necessary sector reforms. The second IIS 
scheduled  in  February  2006  aims  to  continue  attracting  private  investors.  Important 
advancements have been made since the first IIS in regulatory and other reforms, but the 
progress  in  awarding  PPP  contracts  and  achieving  financial  closing  has  been  less  than 
satisfactory.  The  different  sector  ministries  and  SOEs  lack  guidelines  and  coordination  in 
preparing and executing PPP transactions. 
 
8.  Strong coordination at the central level is essential to ensure a consistent PPP approach 
across  the  infrastructure  sectors  and  to  demonstrate,  through  a  few  successful  model 
transactions, that this approach works in Indonesia. The high-level interministerial Committee on 
Policy  for  the  Acceleration  of  Infrastructure  Development  (KKPPI),  created  in  2001  and

and $80 billion from private investors. The World Bank estimates the needs at $20 billion per year, of which only $4

3 
strengthened in 2005, can help achieve this. The KKPPI, which reports directly to the President, 
is co-chaired by the Coordinating Minister of Economic Affairs and the State Minister of National 
Development  Planning/Chairperson  of  the  National  Development  Planning  Agency 
(BAPPENAS), the latter acting as the Executive Chair. Its members include the Ministers of 
Finance,  Home  Affairs,  Energy  and  Mineral  Resources,  Public  Works,  Transportation, 
Communications and Informatics, and State-Owned Enterprises; and the Cabinet Secretary. 
The main tasks of the KKPPI are to formulate strategies and policies for the acceleration of 
infrastructure  development,  coordinate  and  supervise  their  implementation  by  the  sector 
ministries  and  local  governments,  formulate  an  implementation  policy  on  public  service 
obligation (PSO) for infrastructure, and solve problems impeding infrastructure development. 
The KKPPI is served by a Secretariat headed by the Deputy Minister for Infrastructure and 
Regional Development in the Coordinating Ministry of Economic Affairs (CMEA) and the Deputy 
Minister for Infrastructure in BAPPENAS. The Secretariat’s CMEA part is mainly responsible for 
providing administrative support to the KKPPI and maintaining contacts with investors and other 
stakeholders, and the BAPPENAS part for providing technical support to the KKPPI. Both need 
extensive capacity building to fulfill their responsibilities. 
 
9.  For  the  day-to-day  coordination  and  management  of  PPP  transactions,  a  network 
consisting of a central PPP unit under the BAPPENAS part of the KKPPI Secretariat and PPP 
nodes in the sector ministries is being established. The sector ministries will be responsible for 
the execution of the PPP transactions. The PPP unit, on the other hand, will be responsible for 
ensuring policy consistency, quality control and transparency. It will establish standards and 
principles that all transactions must follow, and monitor the execution for compliance. Given the 
massive investment needs against limited capital resources, another important responsibility of 
the PPP unit will be to prioritize projects.  
 
III.  THE PROPOSED TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
10.  The  goal  of  the  proposed  TA  is  to  help,  together  with  various  other  interventions, 
significantly increase infrastructure investments and thereby support the achievement of the 
Government’s economic growth and poverty reduction targets. Its expected outcome is the 
capability to formulate and implement policy and regulatory reforms and to prepare, execute and 
monitor PPP and PSO projects in a coordinated manner. This will be achieved by providing 
support  to  the  KKPPI  Secretariat  in  BAPPENAS,  developing  the  PSO  and  regulatory 
frameworks,  establishing  best  practice  documentation,  preparing  model  PPP  projects,  and 
contributing to the second IIS. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
11.  Given the process character of infrastructure sector reforms, PPP transactions and the 
related capacity building, not all TA activities can be fully defined at this stage. Flexibility in TA 
implementation will therefore be essential, for example by modifying the tasks described below, 
adding new ones, or reallocating consultant resources. The necessary degree of flexibility will 
also be achieved by using mainly short-term experts. 
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
12.  Support and Capacity Building in the KKPPI Secretariat in BAPPENAS. For the 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.  
KKPPI to fulfill its mandate, it is essential that the PPP network functions smoothly and the 
KKPPI Secretariat provides efficient technical and administrative support. The TA will focus on 
capacity building in the KKPPI Secretariat in BAPPENAS, which has been given responsibility

4   
for the technical support. Consultants will be placed in BAPPENAS to act as advisers to the 
Head of the KKPPI Secretariat and to provide on-the-job and formal training to his staff. Part of 
the capacity building will be the development of a set of best practice examples for PPP and 
PSO projects covering the entire project cycle from identification to operation. It will document 
best practices for conducting feasibility studies; preparing tender documents; allocating risks; 
negotiating,  managing,  and  monitoring  agreements;  and  regulating  the  provision  of 
infrastructure services. The main output will be a cross-sector toolkit for PPP and PSO projects.  
 
13.  PSO  Framework.  The  Government  has  been  revising  the  framework  for  PSP  to 
incorporate recent international and domestic experience. A policy document is being prepared 
that will outline the rationale for mainstreaming PPPs as a mechanism for infrastructure service 
delivery,  and  describe  the  roles  and  responsibilities  of  the  various  stakeholders,  the 
implementation arrangements, and the legal and regulatory environment. Once endorsed by the 
Cabinet, the policy document will be presented at the second IIS. A similar strategic framework, 
including an implementation policy and sector-specific guidelines, will be developed under the 
TA for infrastructure services that cannot be delivered on a full-cost recovery basis as low-
income customers would not be able to pay for them (for example, rural water supply and rural 
electrification). The business-as-usual approach of public utilities, which provide these services 
either through cross-subsidies or untargeted government subsidies, is not sustainable. While 
the public sector will have to continue playing a key role, innovative models allowing PSP need 
to be developed, such as output-based aid that is explicit, targeted, and driven by performance 
of the service provider. 
 
14.  Sector Regulation. The regulatory framework in Indonesia is evolving and varies from 
sector to sector. The Directorate General of Electricity and Energy Utilization in the Ministry of 
Energy and Mineral Resources is responsible for regulation in the power sector. BPH Migas 
was established in 2003 as a regulatory body and contracting authority for the downstream 
business  in  the  gas  sector.  The  Indonesian  Toll  Road  Authority,  established  in  2004  and 
reporting to the Minister of Public Works, plays the same role in the road sector. The recently 
established National Water Regulatory Agency, which also reports to the Minister of Public 
Works,  is  intended  to  regulate  water  supply.  For  ports  and  airports,  the  regulatory 
responsibilities are with the SOEs active in these sectors that also play the role of contracting 
authorities and operators. The TA will recommend a practical regulatory framework for all 
infrastructure sectors building on international best practice, local conditions and work already 
undertaken by the Government. For the transition period before independent regulatory bodies 
become fully operational, the TA will develop model regulation-by-contract templates. 
 
15.  Project Screening and Preparation. During the first IIS, the Government offered 91 
projects totaling $22.5 billion to the private sector.3 However, bids have been called only for one 
power plant and six toll roads, mainly because of inadequate project preparation. By reviewing 
the available project documentation, the TA will help screen the projects, define the scope of 
additional preparatory work needed, and determine the best approach to their implementation. 
For selected model projects, the necessary preparatory work will be undertaken. In addition, 
technical and general administrative support will be provided for the second IIS where another 
batch of projects is to be announced. 
 
 
                                                 
3 This offering consisted of 38 toll road projects ($9.4 billion), 12 power projects ($5.9 billion), 6 gas projects ($2.9 
billion), 1 telecommunications project ($1.6 billion), 4 port projects ($ 1.5 billion), 5 airport projects ($ 0.7 billion), 24 
water supply projects ($0.4 billion), and 1 railway project ($0.1 billion).

5 
16.  The proposed TA will be implemented in close coordination with the World Bank’s 
Private Provision of Infrastructure Technical Assistance (PPITA) loan, approved in May 2003 for 
$17.1 million. The PPITA, which is executed through long-term in-house advisors, focuses on 
CMEA, the Ministry of Public Works, the Ministry of Transportation, and the Ministry of Energy 
and  Mineral  Resources.  By  building  capacity  in  BAPPENAS  and  using  mostly  short-term 
experts, duplication of work through the proposed TA will be avoided. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
17.  The total cost of the proposed TA is estimated at $2,500,000 equivalent, including 
foreign exchange of $1,600,000 and local currency of $900,000 equivalent. The Government 
has requested ADB to finance $2,000,000 equivalent to cover the entire foreign exchange cost 
and $400,000 equivalent of the local currency cost. The TA will be financed on a grant basis 
from ADB’s TA funding program. The Government will contribute the remaining cost in kind by 
providing office accommodation in Jakarta, counterpart staff, secretarial support, and workshop 
facilities. Detailed cost estimates and the financing plan are in Appendix 3. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
18.  BAPPENAS  will  be  the  Executing  Agency  for  the  proposed  TA,  and  the  KKPPI 
Secretariat in BAPPENAS will be the Implementing Agency. BAPPENAS will assign a project 
leader  and  suitable  counterpart  staff  to  work  with  the  TA  consultants.  The  TA  will  be 
implemented over 15 months starting in January 2006 and ending in March 2007, and will 
require about 52 person-months of international and 65 person-months of domestic consultants. 
The international consultants will have relevant experience in policy reforms, restructuring, PSP, 
and PPP and PSO project preparation and execution. The domestic consultants will have 
expertise in the relevant infrastructure sectors in Indonesia. Several individual consultants and a 
consulting firm will be engaged by ADB to carry out the various tasks, in accordance with ADB’s 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants and other arrangements satisfactory to ADB for engaging 
domestic consultants. For the consulting firm, simplified technical proposals and the quality and 
cost-based selection method will be used. One of the international consultants will act as the 
team  coordinator  and  will  work  closely  with  the  BAPPENAS  project  leader.  The  team 
coordinator will be responsible for preparing bi-monthly progress reports, and other reports as 
needed. Outline terms of reference for the consultants are in Appendix 4. All procurement under 
the TA will follow ADB’s Guidelines for Procurement. 
 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S RECOMMENDATION 
19.  The President recommends that the Board approve the provision of technical assistance 
not exceeding the equivalent of $2.0 million on a grant basis to the Government of Indonesia for 
the Support for Infrastructure Development.  
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  General 
1.  The technical assistance (TA) will be implemented in close coordination with the World 
Bank’s Private Provision of Infrastructure Technical Assistance (PPITA) to support the high-level 
interministerial Committee on Policy for the Acceleration of Infrastructure Development (KKPPI). 
The PPITA focuses on the KKPPI Secretariat in the Coordinating Ministry of Economic Affairs, 
and on the Ministry of Public Works, Ministry of Transportation, and Ministry of Energy and 
Mineral Resources. To avoid duplication of work, the principal focus of the TA will be the KKPPI 
Secretariat in the National Development Planning Agency (BAPPENAS). 
  
2.  Because  of  the  process  character  of  infrastructure  sector  reforms  and  the  related 
capacity  building,  not  all  TA  activities  can  be  fully  defined  at  this  stage.  Flexibility  in  TA 
implementation will therefore be essential. The tasks listed below may be modified, or new ones 
added, and the consultant inputs in terms of international person-months (IPMs) and domestic 
person-months (DPMs) may be adjusted.  
 
3.  The major part of the TA will be carried out by a consulting firm. However, as the 
selection process will take some time, the services of this firm are unlikely to be available before 
March 2006. Given the urgency of providing support to the KKPPI Secretariat and preparing the 
second Indonesia Infrastructure Summit (IIS) in February 2006, individual consultants will be 
engaged for some of the tasks listed in Section B: (i) one international and one domestic 
individual consultant (12 IPMs and 12 DPMs, respectively) for the support and capacity building 
in the KKPPI Secretariat in BAPPENAS under Task 1; (ii) one international and one domestic 
consultant (1 IPM and 2 DPMs, respectively) for the screening of projects prior to the second IIS 
under Task 5; and (iii) one international and one domestic consultant (1 IPM and 2 DPMs, 
respectively) for the preparation of the second IIS under Task 6. One of the international 
consultants engaged for Task 1 will coordinate the various TA activities; provide the main liaison 
between the Government, the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and the consultants; and, with 
input from the other consultants, prepare progress and final reports.  
 
B.  Main Activities 
 
4.  The responsibilities of the consultants will include the following: 
 
1.  Support and Capacity Building in the KKPPI Secretariat in BAPPENAS (22 
IPMs and 24 DPMs) 
(i)  Coordinate  the  TA  activities  with  the  Government,  World  Bank,  and 
PPITA consultants to avoid any overlaps. 
(ii)  Guide the other international and domestic consultants engaged under 
the TA in their work to ensure that the TA objectives are met. 
(iii)  Prepare bi-monthly progress reports on TA implementation. 
(iv)  With input from the other consultants, prepare a draft final report (after 10 
months), and final report (after 12 months). 
(v)  Act  as  a  long-term  advisor  to  the  Head  of  the  KKPPI  Secretariat  in 
BAPPENAS.

Appendix 4  11 
       
(vi)  Provide support and on-the-job training to BAPPENAS staff in the KKPPI 
Secretariat in rendering technical support to the KKPPI on cross-sector 
and  sector  specific  issues;  evaluating  projects  submitted  by  the  PPP 
nodes in the sector ministries and local governments; preparing briefing 
notes on these projects for the KKPPI; reviewing and finalizing policy 
papers; drafting speeches for senior government officials; liaising with the 
Ministry  of  Finance  on  risk  allocation  and  government  guarantees; 
preparing  guidelines  for  pre-feasibility  and  feasibility  studies,  tender 
documents and project agreements; publishing status reports on PPP 
projects; and disseminating other relevant information.   
(vii)  Provide BAPPENAS staff formal training in the form of workshops on key 
subjects relevant to their responsibilities.  
(viii)  Organize a workshop for staff from the Ministry of Home Affairs and 
selected local governments responsible for infrastructure development to 
familiarize them with the private sector participation and public service 
obligation (PSO) frameworks, and project preparation and execution at 
the sub-national level; and 
(ix)  Assist  the  KKPPI  Secretariat  in  designing  and  implementing  the 
Government’s Infrastructure Reform Program. 
2.  Public Service Obligation Framework (2 IPMs and 3 DPMs) 
(i)  Determine  which  infrastructure  services,  though  vital  for  Indonesia’s 
economic  growth  and  poverty  reduction,  are  not  commercially  viable 
because they do not generate revenues (e.g., rural roads), or because 
the poor may not be able to afford the tariffs based on full cost recovery 
(e.g., rural water supply and rural electrification). 
(ii)  Analyze the current approaches to subsidizing these services and assess 
their sustainability. 
(iii)  Recommend alternative PSO approaches (such as output-based aid) that 
are targeted and performance-driven, and that would allow PSP in, and 
an expansion of, these services to close the gap to the service coverage 
in neighboring countries. 
(iv)  Quantify the financial requirements of the new PSO approaches. 
(v)  Draft a policy document describing proposed PSO framework in terms of 
the  objectives  of  the  policy,  the  rationale  for  the  new  approaches  of 
service delivery, the roles and responsibilities of the various stakeholders, 
the institutional and implementation structure, the legal and regulatory 
environment, and the budgetary implications. 
3.  Sector Regulation (2 IPMs and 5 DPMs)  
 
(i)  Review the current regulatory arrangements for power, gas, toll roads, 
ports,  airports,  railways,  telecommunications,  and  water  supply  and 
sanitation. 
(ii)  Assess  the  potential  conflict  of  interest  arising  from  some  regulatory 
bodies being part of the sector ministries that provide funding, staffing 
and secretarial support, or for assuming other roles such as a contracting 
authority and operator.

12  Appendix 4 
(iii)  Make recommendations on short- and medium-term development of an 
optimum regulatory framework, taking into account both international best 
practice and current conditions in the various infrastructure sectors. 
(iv)  Make recommendations on regulation by contract during the transition 
period before fully functional independent regulatory bodies are in place. 
4.  Best Practice Documentation and Workshop (1 IPM and 2 DPMs) 
(i)  As part of the various activities under this TA, compile information on 
international best practices for PPP and PSO projects, covering the entire 
project cycle from identification to preparation to execution to operation. 
(ii)  Organize a workshop on best international practices in sector regulation 
in  terms  of  unbundling  multiple  roles,  ensuring  administrative  and 
financial autonomy (e.g., through self-financing by fee collection), and 
selecting and appointing board members of regulatory bodies. 
(iii)  Establish a resource base documenting best practices for conducting pre-
feasibility  and  feasibility  studies  (minimum  content);  preparing  tender 
documents (standard Request for Qualification, Request for Proposal, 
Cooperation Agreement, etc.); allocating risks; negotiating, managing and 
monitoring  agreements;  and  using  regulation  by  contract  for  sectors 
without a fully functional independent regulatory body. 
(iv)  Prepare a cross-sector toolkit for PPP and PSO projects. 
5.  Project Screening and Preparation (24 IPMs and 29 DPMs) 
(i)  Review the lists of projects offered to the private sector during the first IIS 
in January 2005 and compiled for the second IIS in February 2006, and 
make a preliminary screening based on the information available. 
(ii)  Based on a detailed review of available reports and other documents, 
assess the status of the readiness for execution of all projects that pass 
the preliminary screening. 
(iii)  For  adequately  prepared  projects,  hold  discussions  with  potential 
investors and financiers to assess their suitability for PSP, prioritize them 
accordingly, and determine the best approach for their implementation.  
(iv)  For  inadequately  prepared  projects,  specify  the  scope  of  additional 
investigations, studies, and other due diligence work required prior to 
offering them to the private sector. 
(v)  For  selected  model  projects,  undertake  the  necessary  additional 
preparatory work such as pre-feasibility studies and bidding documents. 
6.  Preparation of the Second Indonesia Infrastructure Summit (1 IPM and 2 
DPMs)  
(i)  Participate  in  meetings  and  workshops  leading  to  the  second  IIS  in 
February 2006, and help identify the key issues and formulate the summit 
agenda. 
(ii)  Draft  speeches  and  presentations  for  the  Government  and  ADB  as 
necessary. 
(iii)  Assist in administrative and logistical arrangements for the second IIS.
